Yes, there are ways to protect your privacy when using digital payment methods:

1. Use secure payment gateways: Make sure that the digital payment platform you use has robust security features that protect your data, such as encryption and multi-factor authentication.

2. Be mindful of public Wi-Fi: When using public Wi-Fi, avoid making transactions as these networks can be easily hacked. Instead, wait until you're on a secure network or use mobile data.

3. Use pseudonyms if possible: Some digital payment platforms allow you to use pseudonyms instead of your real name. This can help maintain your anonymity.

4. Don't keep too much money in digital wallets: Keeping a large amount of money in digital wallets makes you vulnerable to cyber attacks.

5. Regularly check your transaction history: Keep a close eye on your transaction history and report any inconsistencies immediately. This can help you detect fraudulent transactions early.

While these steps can help protect your privacy, it's important to note that there are some inherent risks associated with digital payments, and ultimately, the responsibility of protecting your privacy falls on you.
